Equality of orthogonal transvection group and elementary orthogonal transvection group

Pratyusha Chattopadhyay
Statistics and Mathematics Unit, Indian Statistical Institute, Bangalore 560 059, India

2010 MSC: 11C20, 13C10, 14L35, 15A24, 15A54, 15A63, 20H25

Key words: elementary orthogonal group, transvection, elementary transvection

Abstract: H. Bass defined orthogonal transvection group of an orthogonal module and elementary orthogonal transvection group of an orthogonal module with a hyperbolic direct summand. We also have the notion of relative orthogonal transvection group and relative elementary orthogonal transvection group with respect to an ideal of the ring. According to the definition of Bass relative elementary orthogonal transvection group is a subgroup of relative orthogonal transvection group of an orthogonal module with hyperbolic direct summand. Here we show that these two groups are the same in the case when the orthogonal module splits locally.

1 Introduction

In Section 5 of [10] L.N. Vaserstein proved that first row of an elementary linear matrix of even size (bigger than or equal to 4) is the same as the first row of a symplectic matrix of the same size w.r.t. an alternating form. This result motivated us to prove that the orbit of a unimodular row of even size under the action of elementary linear group is same as the orbit of a unimodular row of same size under the action of elementary symplectic group (see Theorem 4.1, [4]); we also proved a relative (to an ideal of the ring) version of this result (see Theorem 5.5, [4]). Generalising this result in the setting of finitely generated projective modules involving the transvection groups as defined by H. Bass, we proved that in the case of a symplectic module with a hyperbolic direct summand the orbits of any unimodular element from the symplectic module, under the actions of elementary linear transvection group and the elementary symplectic transvection group coincide(see Theorem 6.1, [5]). While proving the above result on equality of orbits of unimodular elements of symplectic modules, we observed that in the relative case to an ideal of the ring, the equality holds between the linear transvection group and the elementary linear transvection group (see Proposition 4.10, [5]). We also noticed that in the relative case to an ideal of the ring, the symplectic transvection group and the elementary symplectic transvection group coincide (see Theorem 5.23, [5]). In the absolute case the equalities for linear transvection group, symplectic transvection group, and orthogonal transvection group with the corresponding elementary transvection groups were proved in [2]. In view of the above results it is natural to ask whether the equality of orthogonal transvection group and elementary orthogonal transvection group holds in the relative case to an ideal of the ring. In this article we prove the equality of these two groups in the case when the orthogonal module splits locally.

3 Local Global Principle for Relative Elementary Group

In this section we prove Lemma 3.1 and Lemma 3.4 which will be used in proving the main result in the final section. In Lemma 3.4 we obtain the Local-Global Principle for an extended ideal for slightly larger group EO(R,I)2â€‹n1{}_{2n}^{1}(R,I) than the relative group EO(R,I)2â€‹n{}_{2n}(R,I). This group was introduced in the linear case by W. van der Kallen in [7]. The Local-Global Principle for an extended ideal in the linear, orthogonal and symplectic groups was proved in [1].

The line of arguments given in the proofs below closely follow that in the Local-Global principle for an extended ideal in the symplectic case in [5]. However, as far as the the computational details are concerned, there are substantial deviations from [5] in many steps.

Lemma 3.4.

Let ağ‘a be a non-nilpotent element in Rğ‘…R and Î±â€‹(X)ğ›¼ğ‘‹\alpha(X) be in EO2â€‹n1â€‹(Raâ€‹[X],Iaâ€‹[X])superscriptsubscriptEO2ğ‘›1subscriptğ‘…ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘‹subscriptğ¼ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘‹{\rm EO}_{2n}^{1}(R_{a}[X],I_{a}[X]), with Î±â€‹(0)=Iâ€‹dğ›¼0ğ¼ğ‘‘\alpha(0)=Id. The proofs as in Lemma 3.3 in [5] and in Lemma 3.4 in [5] work verbatim for Lemma 3.3 and Lemma 3.4 as above, respectively, and hence the proofs are omitted.

The following result was proved in [1]. We next apply Lemma 3.4 to record a different proof.

Theorem 3.5.

Let Rğ‘…R be a commutative ring and Iğ¼I be an ideal of Rğ‘…R. Let nâ‰¥3ğ‘›3n\geq 3. 4 Orthogonal Modules and Orthogonal Transvections

In this section we prove Theorem 4.22 which is the main result of this paper. We begin with a sequence of definitions.

Definition 4.1.

Let Mğ‘€M be an Rğ‘…R-module. A bilinear form on Mğ‘€M is a function Î²:MÃ—MâŸ¶R:ğ›½âŸ¶ğ‘€ğ‘€ğ‘…\beta:M\times M\longrightarrow R such that Î²â€‹(x,y)ğ›½ğ‘¥ğ‘¦\beta(x,y) is Rğ‘…R-linear as a function of xğ‘¥x for fixed yğ‘¦y, and Rğ‘…R-linear as a function of yğ‘¦y for fixed xğ‘¥x. The pair (M,Î²)ğ‘€ğ›½(M,\beta) is called bilinear form module over Rğ‘…R. Î²ğ›½\beta is called an inner product if it satisfies non-degeneracy condition, i.e, the natural map induced by Î²ğ›½\beta from PâŸ¶Pâˆ—âŸ¶ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘ƒP\longrightarrow P^{*} is an isomorphism. In this case the pair (M,Î²)ğ‘€ğ›½(M,\beta) is called inner product module over Rğ‘…R. A bilinear form or inner product Î²ğ›½\beta is called symmetric if Î²â€‹(x,y)=Î²â€‹(y,x)ğ›½ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ›½ğ‘¦ğ‘¥\beta(x,y)=\beta(y,x), for all x,yâˆˆMğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘€x,y\in M. An inner product module (M,Î²)ğ‘€ğ›½(M,\beta) will be called inner product space if Mğ‘€M is finitely generated and projective over Rğ‘…R.

Definition 4.2.

An orthogonal Rğ‘…R-module is a pair (P,âŸ¨,âŸ©)(P,\langle,\rangle), where Pğ‘ƒP is a finitely generated projective Rğ‘…R-module of even rank and âŸ¨,âŸ©:PÃ—PâŸ¶R\langle,\rangle:P\times P\longrightarrow R is a non-degenerate symmetric bilinear form. This is also known as symmetric inner product space.

Definition 4.3.

Let (P1,âŸ¨,âŸ©1)(P_{1},\langle,\rangle_{1}) and (P2,âŸ¨,âŸ©2)(P_{2},\langle,\rangle_{2}) be two orthogonal Rğ‘…R-modules. Their orthogonal sum is the pair (P,âŸ¨,âŸ©)(P,\langle,\rangle), where P=P1âŠ•P2ğ‘ƒdirect-sumsubscriptğ‘ƒ1subscriptğ‘ƒ2P=P_{1}\oplus P_{2} and the inner product is defined by âŸ¨(p1,p2),(q1,q2)âŸ©=âŸ¨p1,q1âŸ©1+âŸ¨p2,q2âŸ©2subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2subscriptsubscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘11subscriptsubscriptğ‘2subscriptğ‘22\langle(p_{1},p_{2}),(q_{1},q_{2})\rangle=\langle p_{1},q_{1}\rangle_{1}+\langle p_{2},q_{2}\rangle_{2}.

Definition 4.4.

There is a non-degenerate symmetric bilinear form âŸ¨,âŸ©\langle,\rangle on the Rğ‘…R-module RâŠ•Râˆ—direct-sumğ‘…superscriptğ‘…R\oplus R^{*}, namely âŸ¨(a1,f1),(a2,f2)âŸ©=f2â€‹(a1)+f1â€‹(a2)subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘“1subscriptğ‘2subscriptğ‘“2subscriptğ‘“2subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘“1subscriptğ‘2\langle(a_{1},f_{1}),(a_{2},f_{2})\rangle=f_{2}(a_{1})+f_{1}(a_{2}). The orthogonal module RâŠ•Râˆ—direct-sumğ‘…superscriptğ‘…R\oplus R^{*} with this symmetric bilinear form is denoted by â„â€‹(R)â„ğ‘…\mathbb{H}(R) and called hyperbolic plane. Note that â„nâ€‹(R)superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘…\mathbb{H}^{n}(R) is the orthogonal sum of nğ‘›n-copies of â„â€‹(R)â„ğ‘…\mathbb{H}(R).

Definition 4.5.

An isometry of an orthogonal module (P,âŸ¨,âŸ©)(P,\langle,\rangle) is an automorphism of Pğ‘ƒP which fixes the bilinear form. The group of isometries of (P,âŸ¨,âŸ©)(P,\langle,\rangle) is denoted by Oâ€‹(P)Oğ‘ƒ{\rm O}(P).

Lemma 4.13.

Definition 4.16.

An orthogonal module (P,âŸ¨,âŸ©)(P,\langle,\rangle) over the ring Rğ‘…R is called split if there exists a submodule NâŠ†Pğ‘ğ‘ƒN\subseteq P such that Nğ‘N is a direct summand of Pğ‘ƒP and such that Nğ‘N is precisely equal to its orthogonal complement NâŸ‚={pâˆˆP:âŸ¨p,nâŸ©=0â€‹forâ€‹allâ€‹nâˆˆN}superscriptğ‘perpendicular-toconditional-setğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘›0forallğ‘›ğ‘N^{\perp}=\{p\in P:\langle p,n\rangle=0~{}{\rm for~{}all}~{}n\in N\}.

Moreover, an orthogonal module (P,âŸ¨,âŸ©)(P,\langle,\rangle) over the ring Rğ‘…R is called locally split if (Pğ”ª,âŸ¨,âŸ©)(P_{\mathfrak{m}},\langle,\rangle) is a split orthogonal Rğ”ªsubscriptğ‘…ğ”ªR_{\mathfrak{m}}-module for every maximal ideal ğ”ªğ”ª\mathfrak{m} of Rğ‘…R.

Lemma 4.17.

(See Lemma 6.3, Chapter I in [9]) Let Rğ‘…R be a ring such that every finitely generated projective module over Rğ‘…R is free. Then an inner product space over Rğ‘…R is split if and only if it possesses a basis so that the associated inner product matrix has the form (0IIA)0ğ¼ğ¼ğ´\big{(}\begin{smallmatrix}0&I\\ I&A\end{smallmatrix}\big{)}. If we also assume that 222 is a unit in the ring, then every split inner product space has matrix (0II0)0ğ¼ğ¼0\big{(}\begin{smallmatrix}0&I\\ I&0\end{smallmatrix}\big{)} with respect to a suitable basis.

Remark 4.18.

In view of Proposition 4.15 and above lemma, for any split orthogonal module (P,âŸ¨,âŸ©Ï†)(P,\langle,\rangle_{\varphi}) over a local ring (R,ğ”ª)ğ‘…ğ”ª(R,\mathfrak{m}) with R=2â€‹Rğ‘…2ğ‘…R=2R, we have TransO(Q,IQ,âŸ¨,âŸ©Ïˆ~1âŸ‚Ï†)=ETransO(Q,IQ,âŸ¨,âŸ©Ïˆ~1âŸ‚Ï†){\rm Trans}_{{\rm O}}(Q,IQ,\langle,\rangle_{\widetilde{\psi}_{1}\perp\varphi})={\rm ETrans}_{{\rm O}}(Q,IQ,\langle,\rangle_{\widetilde{\psi}_{1}\perp\varphi}). Here Iğ¼I is an ideal of the ring Rğ‘…R.

Next we establish dilation principle for relative elementary orthogonal transvection group.

We now establish equality of the orthogonal transvection group and the elementary orthogonal transvection group (in the relative case to an ideal) of a locally split orthogonal Rğ‘…R-module with R=2â€‹Rğ‘…2ğ‘…R=2R. An absolute version of this result (i.e, when I=Rğ¼ğ‘…I=R) was proved in [2] (see Theorem 3.10). Before proving the main result we establish a lemma to show that orthogonal transvections are homotopic to identity.

Theorem 4.22.

Let Rğ‘…R be a commutative ring with R=2â€‹Rğ‘…2ğ‘…R=2R, and let Iğ¼I be an ideal of Rğ‘…R. Proof: We have ETransO(Q,IQ,âŸ¨,âŸ©)âŠ†TransO(Q,IQ,âŸ¨,âŸ©){\rm ETrans}_{{\rm O}}(Q,IQ,\langle,\rangle)\subseteq{\rm Trans}_{{\rm O}}(Q,IQ,\langle,\rangle). We need to show other inclusion. Hence Î±â€‹(X)ğ”ªğ›¼subscriptğ‘‹ğ”ª\alpha(X)_{\mathfrak{m}} belongs to ETransO(Qğ”ª[X],IQğ”ª[X],âŸ¨,âŸ©Ïˆ~1âŸ‚Ï†âŠ—Rğ”ªâ€‹[X]){\rm ETrans}_{{\rm O}}(Q_{\mathfrak{m}}[X],IQ_{\mathfrak{m}}[X],\langle,\rangle_{\widetilde{\psi}_{1}\perp\varphi\otimes R_{\mathfrak{m}}[X]}), for each maximal ideal ğ”ªğ”ª\mathfrak{m} of Rğ‘…R. Remark 4.24.
